title.value: Reproducible Spinal Cord Quantitative MRI Analysis with the Spinal Cord Toolbox
title.justification: This title accurately encapsulates the major focus of the paper, which is the reproducible analysis of spinal cord MRI data using Spinal Cord Toolbox (SCT).
title.quote: Reproducible Spinal Cord Quantitative MRI Analysis with the Spinal Cord Toolbox

extractions.description: This paper reviews the advancements in spinal cord MRI data acquisition and analysis, emphasizing the importance of using standardized protocols, open-access datasets, and software tools like the Spinal Cord Toolbox (SCT) to ensure reproducibility and reliability of results. It discusses various quantitative MRI techniques, the significance of open-access datasets, and the features and utilities offered by SCT.

type.justification: The paper is primarily a review of the current state of spinal cord MRI analysis and does not present new empirical research but rather discusses existing methods, datasets, and the Spinal Cord Toolbox.
type.quote: In this review, we briefly introduce spinal cord MRI, cover the standardized spinal cord MRI acquisition protocol, discuss the importance of open-access datasets for reproducible science, and describe some features of the analysis software package Spinal Cord Toolbox (SCT).

name.justification: The primary focus is on spinal cord MRI, a crucial medical imaging technique.
name.quote: Recent advancements in spinal cord MRI data acquisition and analysis have proven to be useful in diagnosis and prognosis, providing valuable insights into the pathophysiology of these conditions and aiding in their management.

name.justification: The paper extensively discusses the acquisition, standardization, and analysis of spinal cord MRI data.
name.quote: Spinal cord MRI can be categorized into conventional and quantitative MRI techniques.

name.justification: The paper addresses neuroimaging specifically related to the spinal cord and its pathologies.
name.quote: Spinal cord MRI has become a critical tool for understanding and managing spinal-cord-related conditions.

name.value: single-subject (19 sites) and multi-subject (N = 267, 43 sites) dataset
name.justification: This dataset consists of structural and microstructural spinal cord MRI scans.
name.quote: The single-subject (19 sites) and multi-subject (N = 267, 43 sites) dataset consists of structural (T1w, T2w, T2*w) and microstructural (magnetization transfer and diffusion MRI) scans acquired using the spine-generic protocol. It has rapidly become a reference dataset for methods development.

referenced_paper_title.value: Open-access quantitative MRI data of the spinal cord and reproducibility across participants, sites and manufacturers.
referenced_paper_title.justification: The role of this dataset as a reference for methods development is emphasized.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The single-subject (19 sites) and multi-subject (N = 267, 43 sites) dataset consists of structural (T1w, T2w, T2*w) and microstructural (magnetization transfer and diffusion MRI) scans acquired using the spine-generic protocol.

name.value: Spinal Cord Head Position MRI dataset
name.justification: This dataset contains T2w scans used for evaluating the pontomedullary junction as a reference for spinal cord cross-sectional area.
name.quote: The Spinal Cord Head Position MRI dataset (https://openneuro.org/datasets/ds004507/) contains T2w scans from 10 healthy participants with 3 different neck positions: flexion, neutral, and extension.

name.justification: This dataset comprises conventional and microstructural MRI data scanned over 3 years for longitudinal analysis.
name.quote: The Courtois-NeuroMod longitudinal dataset (https://github.com/courtois-neuromod/anat) contains conventional and microstructure MRI data of 6 participants scanned at regular intervals over 3 years with up to ten sessions per participant.

referenced_paper_title.value: Longitudinal stability of brain and spinal cord quantitative MRI measures.
referenced_paper_title.justification: This dataset was used in the study for longitudinal measurements.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The Courtois-NeuroMod longitudinal dataset (https://github.com/courtois-neuromod/anat) contains conventional and microstructure MRI data of 6 participants scanned at regular intervals over 3 years with up to ten sessions per participant.

name.justification: This dataset is used for the segmentation challenge to visualize the spinal cord gray matter.
name.quote: To visualize the spinal cord gray matter, there is a dataset (N = 80) used in a segmentation challenge.

name.value: task-based dataset for spinal cord functional MRI
name.justification: This dataset was used in the study of spinal cord spatial activity distribution.
name.quote: Concerning spinal cord functional MRI, a task-based dataset (N = 30 participants) (https://openneuro.org/datasets/ds004616/) was used during the study of spinal cord spatial activity distribution during a hand-grasp motor task.

name.justification: This dataset features resting-state data and was used to investigate the reliability of spinal cord resting-state functional connectivity.
name.quote: Another functional MRI dataset (https://openneuro.org/datasets/ds004386/) features resting-state data (N = 45 participants) and was used to investigate the reliability of spinal cord resting-state functional connectivity.

name.justification: Although focused on the brain, the upper cervical spinal cord in the T1w brain images was used for developing a normalization method.
name.quote: The UK Biobank database is another potential source of MRI images. Although primarily focused on the brain, the upper cervical spinal cord captured in the T1w brain images was used to develop a normalization method based on the pontomedullary junction.
